titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Victor F. Germack and Lori Shepard Germack Collection of Photographs of Indians of North America
Germack (Victor F.) and Lori Shepard Germack Collection of Photographs of Indians of North America
titlestmt.author: by Matthew Daniel Mason and Anna M. Ferris

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:40

did.unittitle: Victor F. Germack and Lori Shepard Germack Collection of Photographs of Indians of North America.

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: This collection consists chiefly of photographic materials created circa 1850-1978 that depict American Indians, including informal and studio portraits, as well as photographs that show the natural and built environment of the American West. Images of the American West include views of cities and towns, mining and logging operations, railroads, and natural scenery.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Vintage Photographic on the Frederick W. and Carrie S. Beinecke Fund for Western Americana and Walter McClintock Memorial Fund, 2007.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Victor F. Germack and Lori Shepard Germack Collection of Photographs of Indians of North America is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Victor F. Germack and Lori Shepard Germack Collection of Photographs of Indians of North America. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Identification of individual items derived from a database created by the collectors. Variations in spellings and capitalization came from the database or the original items.

Many entries for individual photographic items that depict American Indians include names translated into English, as well as transliterated from their native languages. American Indian individuals are often known by several names; the expressions of names for American Indians in this collection usually reflect their most well-known names. The processing archivists did not attempt to capture all the known names for individuals.

bioghist.head: Victor F. Germack (born 1939) and Lori Shepard Germack (born 1942)
bioghist.p: Victor F. Germack, and his wife, Lori Shepard Germack, are collectors of photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists chiefly of photographic materials created circa 1850-1978 that depict American Indians, including informal and studio portraits, as well as photographs that show the natural and built environment of the American West. Images of the American West include views of cities and towns, mining and logging operations, railroads, and natural scenery.

The collection comprises a broad range of photographic formats including cased photographs, tintypes, card photographs, stereographs, transparencies, photographic postcards, and other photographic prints, as well as photograph albums and photographically illustrated books. Other visual resources in the collection include printed material, such as picture postcards, cigarette cards, playing cards, and photomechanical prints.

Prominent photographers represented in the collection include David Francis Barry, William Henry Brown, Alexander Gardner, Benjamin Arthur Gifford, Francis Asher Hartwell, John Karl Hillers, William H. Illingworth, Truman Ward Ingersoll, William Henry Jackson, Charles Fletcher Lummis, Thomas Leander Moorhouse, Stanley Julius Morrow, Adolph F. Muhr, Timothy H. O'Sullivan, Frank Albert Rinehart, Joel Emmons Whitney, and Benjamin Wittick.
Major studios, photograph cooperatives, and companies represented in the collection include Florida Club, Keystone View Company, and Thomas Houseworth & Co.

A significant group of photographs by Francis Chickering Briggs and Munroe Chickering document students, buildings, and environs of the Santee Normal Training School in Santee, Nebraska, in 1877, as well as schools at the Cheyenne River Reservation in the Dakota Territory and the Ponca Agency in Nebraska.
Each folder contains a single item, except when noted in the description.
Material in the collection are arranged by type and size, consequently images by a single photographer may appear in multiple series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into eight series: I. Cased Photographs, Tintypes, and Orotone, circa 1850-circa 1960. II. Card Photographs, 1863-circa 1910. III. Stereographs, circa 1860-circa 1925. IV. Photographic Prints, 1862-1927. V. Photograph Albums and Photographically Illustrated Volumes, 1875-circa 1969. VI. Photographic Transparencies, circa 1878-circa 1920. VII. Postcards, circa 1900-1978. VIII. Printed Material and Press Kit, 1899-1975.

did.unittitle: Cased Photographs, Tintypes, and Orotone

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into four subseries: Daguerreotype, Ambrotypes, Tintypes, and Orotone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of a daguerreotype, two ambrotypes, and fifteen tintypes by unidentified photographers, as well as an orotone by Arthur Clarence Pillsbury.

did.unittitle: Orotone
Pillsbury, Arthur Clarence
American Indian Infant in a Cradleboard
Card Photographs

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Created chiefly during the nineteenth century, card photographs encompass commercially-produced photographs mounted on thick cardboard that have dimensions slightly larger than the photographic prints. The photographer's name or insignia is usually printed or embossed on the cardboard mount. The versos of the cards often bear the imprint of the photographer.
Images by a single photographer may appear in multiple subseries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into seven subseries: Cartes-de-visite, Cabinet Photographs, Imperial Photographs, Promenade Photographs, Boudoir Photographs, Victoria Cards, and Other Card Photographs.

did.unittitle: Cartes-de-visite

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Introduced in 1854, the carte-de-visite, or carte, was generally a 5.7 x 8.9 centimeters (2.25 x 3.5 inches) photograph, usually a full or bust-length portrait of an individual, mounted on a 6.4 x 10.2 centimeters (2.5 x 4 inches) paper card.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by photographer or studio followed by material made by unidentified creators.

Southern Plains Delegation of American Indians in the White House Conservatory, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The American Indians in the front row, left to right: War Bonnet, Standing in the Water, and Lean Bear, all Cheyenne Indians, as well as Yellow Wolf, a Kiowa Indian. The American Indians in the second row are unidentified.
Interpreter William Simpson Smith and the agent Samuel G. Colley stand at the left of the group.
The European American woman standing at the far right is identified as Mary Todd Lincoln.

Mounted Cartes-de-visite

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fifteen cartes-de-visite including portraits of Ute Indians, Crow Indians, Dakota Indians, Cheyenne Indians, Arapahoe Indians, Comanche Indians and Navajo Indians, compiled and mounted on a board by William Gunnison Chamberlain.

Individuals include: Navajo Indian woman, Juanita, wife of Manuelito, by William Henry Jackson, circa 1885; Ute Indian man, Tab-u-cha-kat, by William Gunnison Chamberlain, circa 1862-77; Crow Indian woman; White River Ute Indian man, Chief Uncachef; an Unca Indian chief, No. 4210, by William Henry Jackson; Ute Indian Chief, Johnson; Spotted Tail, Sioux chief by William Gunnison Chamberlain, circa 1875; Group photo of Cheyenne Indian and Arapaho Indian chiefs; Ma-Ha; Yorn-Ko, Ouray's runner; Washington, a Ute Indian chief; and other Braves and Warriors.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by photographer or studio followed by material made by unidentified creators.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Introduced in 1862, cabinet photographs were photographic prints with dimensions around 11.4 x 16.5 centimeters (4.5 by 6.5 inches) mounted on cardboard and generally used for portraits.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Associated Materials: Additional cabinet photographs can also be found in Series V. Photograph Albums and Volumes.

Imperial Photographs

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by photographer or studio followed by material made by unidentified creators.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Introduced circa 1863, imperial photographs were photographic prints mounted on cardboard with dimensions approximately 17.5 by 25.4 centimeters (6.9 by 10 inches), as well as 20 by 25.1 centimeters (7.9 by 9.9 inches).
This format is distinct from another format also known as imperial photographs, introduced in 1856, with print dimensions approximately 43.2 centimeters by 53.3 centimeters (17 by 20 inches).

Stereographs

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Stereographs are double photographic prints that depict the same image taken from two slightly different perspectives and mounted on cards. Viewing the two-dimensional images through a stereoscope creates the illusion of a three-dimensional image to the viewer.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is arranged alphabetically by photographer or publisher followed by stereographs created by unidentified creators.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Entries for individual stereographs include their titles, numbers on the mounts, and their series. The entries also document if no numbers or series information exists.

Discrete groups of entries for stereographs published by Truman Ward Ingersoll and the Keystone View Company are arranged by series when known. Stereographs by these photographers without an identified series are arranged by their titles and numbers.
Occasionally, to clarify the image content of particular stereographs, entries may include descriptions of the images.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Associated Materials: A stereograph transparency can be found in Series VI. Photographic Transparencies.

Keystone View Company

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: From 1892 to 1963, the Keystone View Company produced and distributed stereographs and lantern slides for educational institutions and the public from its headquarters in Meadville, Pennsylvania.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two groups: "I" Series and Unidentified Series

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stereograph cards produced by the Keystone View Company often include several numbers printed on their mounts that document the image. The numbers that appear in the upper center of the stereograph document the position of that card within a particular set.
Additional numbers on the recto or verso of the card designate the negative number for the pair of images.
Numbers with a "P" prefix designate the card as part of an educational set designed for elementary school age children.
This group includes examples of images originally created for companies that the Keystone View Company acquired later.
Numbers with a "W" prefix were images originally created or copyrighted by the H. C. White Company, which sold its stereographic stock and rights to the Keystone View Company in 1915.
Numbers with a "V" prefix were images originally created or copyrighted by the Underwood & Underwood Company, which sold its stereographic stock and rights to the Keystone View Company in 1920.

did.unittitle: "I" Series

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged sequentially by the "I" series number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Set of stereographs with an unidentified title produced and distributed by the Keystone View Company, circa 1922, that depict different American Indian groups.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged under headings for identified sites followed by unidentified images and an example of stationery from the mission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs created in the fall of 1877 by Francis Chickering Briggs (1833-1908), business agent at Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute, Virginia. The images document students, buildings, and environs of the Santee Normal Training School in Santee, Nebraska, as well as schools at the Cheyenne River Reservation, Dakota Territory, and Ponca Agency, Nebraska, probably by his maternal cousin, Munroe Chickering (born 1846).

Photographic prints created by Briggs are represented in the collection by prints with larger dimensions, usually 16.5 x 21.5 centimeters. These prints also possess manuscript numbers on their versos, which are occasionally visible in the negatives. Photographic prints created by Munroe have smaller dimensions, usually 11 x 19 centimeters, and often have his name and brief captions on their versos.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Santee Normal Training School in Santee, Nebraska, prepared its students (both male and female children and youths from the Dakota Indian tribes) to enter the teaching or preaching professions, as well as giving classes in industrial arts and home economics.

Reverend Alfred Longley Riggs (1837-1916) founded the Santee Normal Training School in 1870, and it continued to operate well into the twentieth century. Unlike many other schools which insisted on students speaking English, the Santee School allowed its pupils to continue to use their native language; several courses were taught in the Dakota language.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group consists of unmounted half stereograph prints issued as St. Augustine Views . They depict views of Castillo de San Marcos in Saint Augustine, Florida, which was known as Fort Marion from 1819 to 1942. Beginning in 1875, American Indian prisoners from the Indian Wars in the western United States were held at Fort Marion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frank Albert Rinehart (circa 1862-1928) was the official photographer for the United States Indian Congress of the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition, held in Omaha, Nebraska, between June 1 and October 31, 1898. During the Congress, Rinehart and/or his assistant Adolph F. Muhr (circa 1858-1913) photographed more than 500 individuals and groups representing the estimated thirty-six tribes represented at the Exposition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photograph albums and photographically illustrated volumes that include images of American Indians and the Trans-Mississippi West.

did.unittitle: Photograph Album of Cabinet Photographs by William Stinson Soule Compiled by Louis Root Spencer

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Louis Root Spencer (1854-1876) was born in Connecticut, the son of Calvin Spencer (1813-1866) and Clarissa M. Root (1820-1899). Spencer served as a paymaster's clerk with the United States Army. On May 22, 1876, robbers shot him near Eureka, California, during a holdup, and he died of his wounds after an amputation of an arm.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Formerly owned by Nelson Case Taintor (Yale 1909). Louis Root Spencer was his maternal uncle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An album compiled by Louis R. Spencer comprised of cabinet photographs created by William Stinson Soule that depict American Indian men and women in the vicinity of Fort Sill, Indian Territory. Groups include Arapaho Indians, Caddo Indians, Cheyenne Indians, Comanche Indians, Kiowa Apache, Kiowa Indians, and Wichita Indians.
Images of Arapaho Indians in 1867 include portraits of Bird Chief, Little Raven, Powder Face, and Shibonester or Shib-O-Nes-Ter , as well as a view of the camp of Cut Hair.
A sole portrait of a Caddo Indian depicts Chief George Washington in 1867.

The album includes images of Kiowa Indians from 1867 to 1872. Portraits created in 1867 include Big Bow (Zepko-Ette), Salose or Sa-Lo-So (Son of White Bear), Tar-Lo, Tibone (Tau-Ankia, Son of Lone Wolf), Trailing the Enemy (To-Me-Ath-To or Eonah-Pah) and his Wife, White Bear (Satanta), and Woman's Heart (Manyi-Ten), as well as a man identified as possibly Standing-Sweat-House (Tape-day-ah). A 1868 portrait depicts Kicking Bird (Tene-Angpote). Portraits created in 1870 include Big Tree (Ado-Eette), Lone Wolf (Guipago), Not Afraid or Not Afraid of Any Indian (Ka-Ati-Wertz-Ama-Na), the sister of Chief Big Tree, Stumbling Bear (Set-Imkia), and White Horse (Tsen-T-Ainte). A portrait created in 1872 depicts Sun Boy. Other images of Kiowa Indians include an unidentified man and unidentified women, as well as a view of a Kiowa Indian camp with tipis, probably the camp of Lone Wolf or Kicking Bear.
Images of Wichita Indians include a portrait of Nawatry, a Wichita Indian Woman, as well as portraits of unidentified women. There is also a view of a Wichita Indian camp with children.

Images of Comanche Indians in 1867 include portraits of Grey Leggings (Asa-To-Yet or Esa-Ton-Yett), Hand Shaker (Mow-Way), Heap Wolves, Horse Back (Ta-Her-Ye-Qua-Hip), Otter Belt, Son of Horse Back, and Standing-Sweat-House (Tape-day-ah), as well as portraits of Comanche Indian women, Chi-Wek-Kiethe and her sister, Looking For Something Good (Cha-Wa-Ke). There is also a view of the Comanche Indian camp of Hand Shaker (Mow-Way).

Images of Cheyenne Indians include a portrait of Cheyenne Indian Women Sauke and Hat-Py or Hathy in 1867, and a Cheyenne Indian camp in 1869 that includes scout and interpreter Horace Pope Jones (1829-1901).
Portrait of Kiowa Apache Indians in 1867 include Pacer and his son, as well as Black Hawk.
A portrait in the album depicts a European American boy allegedly held captive by American Indians.

did.unittitle: William Henry Jackson, Colorado (Denver: W. H. Jackson)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Distributed Benjamin Austin Taft in Silverton, Colorado.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Volume of sixteen photographs created by William Henry Jackson mounted on twelve boards folded in concertina style, which depict views of Colorado, 1882.

The sequence of images in the volume includes: Durango, Colorado (No. 3214); Cañon of the Rio Las Animas (No. 3260); Needle Mountains from Animas Cañon (No. 2885); Deer Park Cascade, Animas Cañon (No. 3258); Elk Park, Animas Cañon (No. 3257); Silverton (No. 3256); Silverton (No. 3265); and Baker's Park (No. 3243), and then followed by the next sequence of images that represent half stereograph views: Cunningham Gulch, Baker's Park (No. 3131); A Mountain Trail (No. 3132); Silverton from the Cascade (No. 3152); Needle Mountains from Baker's Park (No. 3153); Cascade Below Silverton (No. 3154); Cascade Below Silverton (No. 3155); Cascade Near Elk Park, Animas Cañon (No. 3156); and Deer Park Cascade, Animas Cañon (No. 3156).

did.unittitle: Album of Seattle, Snoqualmie Hop Ranch, and Logging Operations in Washington with Photographs by John P. Soule

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The album of photographs created by professional photographer John P. Soule, circa 1890-1893, that document the reconstruction of Seattle, Washington, after the Great Fire of 1889, as well as a hops farm and logging operations in northwestern Washington.

Images of Seattle include views of Front Street, coal bunkers, and lumber mills, as well as a camp of American Indian hop pickers on the waterfront. Identified buildings and city blocks include Burke Building, Chamber of Commerce Building, Harrisburg Block, Hotel Rainier, John Cort's Standard Theatre, King County Courthouse, Occidental Hotel, Olympic Block, and Pioneer Building, as well as the powerhouse for cable cars on the Union Trunk Line.

Images of ships in the vicinity of Seattle include the United States Revenue Cutter Bear and United States Cruiser Charleston, as well as the Mary L. Burrill loading the first shipment wheat on November 3, 1890, from the grain terminal in West Seattle.
A group of images document American Indian hop pickers at the Snoqualmie Hop Ranch in Snoqualmie, Washington, as well as a ferry at the farm.
Photographs of logging operations include the logging camp of John Edgecomb in Snohomish County and logging by the Huron Lumber Company in Bothell, as well as ships loading lumber at Port Blakeley.

did.unittitle: Album of Trip from Nebraska to Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An album by an unidentified compiler. Photographs created by professional photographers document sites along a journey from Omaha, Nebraska through Colorado, Utah, California, New Mexico, Missouri, Georgia, South Carolina, to Virginia, January 13 to March 17, 1893. The compiler then traveled from New York on April 5 to Liverpool on April 13 in the saloon class aboard the SS Teutonic .
Images of Omaha, Nebraska, visited January 13, include the Bee Building, Douglas County Courthouse, Omaha City Hall, and Paxton Hotel.

Images of Colorado, visited January 18-24, include views of Denver, Garden of the Gods, and Colorado Springs. Images of Denver include Arapahoe County Court House, Colorado State Capitol, Denver High School, Equitable Building, and St. John's Episcopal Cathedral. Images of Garden of the Gods and Colorado Springs include photographs by William Edward Hook that depict rock outcroppings and waterfalls, as well as an image of the summit of Pike's Peak with the Army Signal Station and a locomotive from the Manitou and Pike's Peak Railway.
Images of Salt Lake City, Utah, visited January 25, include the gravesite of Brigham Young, the Tabernacle and Temple in Salt Lake City, and the Garfield Beach and Pavilion on the Great Salt Lake.

Images of California, visited January 27 to February 14, include views of San Francisco, Monterey, and Santa Cruz by Isaiah West Taber. Photographs of San Francisco include Chinatown, Golden Gate Park, Golden Gate, and Goat Island, as well as Sutro Heights and Cliff House, including adjacent Seal Rocks. Several images document Hotel del Monte in Monterey, including the Arizona Garden. Photographs of Santa Cruz depict coast redwood trees, including Grizzly Giant. Other images of sites in California include the ranch of Joel Parker Whitney in Rocklin, as well as views of sites in Los Angeles by C.C. Pierce & Co., including the avenue of palms at the homestead of Charles A. Longstreet.

Images of New Mexico, visited February 17, include photographs by Dana B. Chase of sites in Santa Fe, including the San Miguel Church and the Palace of the Governors, as well as portraits of American Indians, including Signor Peso, the chief of the scouts who captured Geronimo. Other portraits of American Indians attributed to Joseph Parker include Hopi Indians, Laguna Indians, Mojave Indians, and Navajo Indians.
Images of Missouri, visited February 19 to March 2, include overviews of Kansas City and its stockyards, as well as the Saint Louis School and Museum of Fine Arts and Eads Bridge in Saint Louis.
Images of Atlanta, Georgia, visited March 7-12, include views of Grant Park and the Georgia State Capitol.
Photographs of South Carolina, visited March 12-17, include the South Carolina Lunatic Asylum in Columbia, as well as Saint Michael's Episcopal Church and residences on the Battery in Charleston.
Images of Richmond, Virginia, visited March 17, include Libby Prison, Old Stone House, and St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

did.unittitle: Album of American Indians Compiled by Patrick Cavanaugh Smith

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Patrick Cavanaugh Smith (1886-1973) was a painter and artist in Louisville, Kentucky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An album compiled by Patrick Cavanaugh Smith in 1902 of photographs and photomechanical prints that depict American Indians. The album includes twenty-six photographs created by John F. Byrnes and Company that depict unidentified performers in Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show, as well as two chromolithographic portraits of performers by William M. Rau. The album also includes thirty-two halftones of images of identified American Indians created by Frank Albert Rinehart and Adolph F. Muhr, 1898-1899.

The album also includes eight copy photographs distributed by the Pioneer Roll Paper Co. that depict portraits of American Indians. Discrete portraits by William Stinson Soule originally created in 1867 include Comanche Indian men Grey Leggings (Asa-To-Yet or Esa-Ton-Yett), Horse Back (Ta-Her-Ye-Qua-Hip), and Tosh-A-Wah (misidentified as Turtle Dove or Co-U-Wa); Kiowa Indian men Big Bow (Zepko-Ette or Ate-te-leaf) and Woman's Heart (Manyi-Ten); and Arapaho Indian Man Little Raven. There is also a copy photograph of Not Afraid or Not Afraid of Any Indian (Ka-Ati-Wertz-Ama-Na), a Kiowa Indian Man, originally created by Soule in 1870. Another copy photograph depicts a portrait of Striker (Da-Ho or Ta-Ho), an Apache Indian man, created by William P. Bliss, circa 1867. An unidentified portrait of a European American man posed standing and wearing American Indian regalia.

did.unittitle: Sample Album of Photographs of American Indians Created by Oxford & Dillhoff

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sample photograph album of twenty-two mounted studio portrait photographs of American Indian performers in the Buffalo Bill Wild West Show created in May 1902 by the photographic studio of Oxford & Dillhoff in Brooklyn, New York.

Identified individuals include William Fire Thunder (No.16568), Dreaming Bear (No.16571), Good Bird (No.16573), Mary Picket Pin (No.16580), Holy Bear (No.16585), Brings Plenty (No.16588), Iron White Man and his wife (No.16592), Iron White Man (No.16594), Henry Horse (No.16600), Two Bull (No.16603), Makes Good (No.16605), Sammy Long Bear (No.16609), Samuel American Horse (No.16613), Mrs. Samuel American Horse (No.16617), Come Last (No.16619), Charlie Picket Pin (No.16621), Conquering Bear (No.16625), Conquering Bear and White Coyote (No.16626), White Coyote (No.16631), Good Crow (No.16634), John Come After (No.16635), and Augustus Between Lodges (No.16636).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The volumes may derive from a project by Royal Sutton, a former president of the Rinehart-Mardsen Studio in Omaha to reproduce the content of folio volumes originally created by George Marsden (1886-1966) of the Rinehart-Mardsen Studio with backing from the J. L. Brandeis and Sons Store. The original folio volumes were likely created for the world premiere of the film Union Pacific , which took place in Omaha on April 28, 1939, during a four-day celebration known as "Golden Spike Days," which celebrated the joining of the Central Pacific and Union Pacific railroads in 1869.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two octavo volumes, created circa 1969, each containing 65 electrophotographic prints that reproduce portraits of American Indians created by Frank A. Rinehart or his assistant Adolph F. Muhr of participants in the Indian Congress of the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition, held in Omaha, Nebraska, between June 1 and October 31, 1898. A leaf containing identification, some with a brief biographical sketch, precede each print.

The volumes are bound in buckskin with pyrographically inscribed titles, volume designations, and decorations on their covers, as well as boards comprised of thick leather with pyrographically decorated interiors. Nancy L. Hontz created the pyrographic decorations based on American Indian motifs.

scopecontent.p: Incomplete set of lantern slides that depict sites in the Western United States. Images include views of Canyon de Chelly, Grand Canyon, Yellowstone National Park, and Yosemite National Park, as well as Garden of the Gods and Pikes Peak in Colorado.
The slides do not have identifying captions or inscriptions.
Extant lantern slides include No. 1, 12-14, 16-22, 24-27, 31, 33-40, 42-44, 49-50, 52-57, 57a, 58-71. There are also two transparencies numbered No. 70.

Cigarette Cards

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Cigarette cards depicted pictures of animals, persons, or other popular culture subjects. They were packaged by manufacturers of cigarettes with their product during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Associated Materials: Cigarette cards with mounted photographic prints can also be found in Series II. Card Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Issued by Allen & Ginter in 1888, the Celebrated American Indian Chiefs set depicts fifty different American Indian men in a complete set, not including cards with caption errors. The source images for the chromolithographic representations of American Indian men on many of the cards derive from photographs created during visits by American Indian delegations to Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Allen & Ginter was a tobacco manufacturing firm formed in Richmond, Virginia, by John Allen and Lewis Ginter in 1875. The firm created and marketed the first cigarette cards for collecting and trading.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The entries for cards in this collection include parenthetical references for the correct tribal affiliation of the depicted individual when appropriate.

did.unittitle: Cards from the Celebrated American Indian Chiefs Set

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wooden frame with an American Indian motif that holds 29 cards from the Celebrated American Indian Chiefs Set.

Cards include: Agate Arrow Point, a Warm Springs Indian (Salish Indian); Always Riding, a Yampah Ute Indian; Big Bear, a Missouria Indian (Missouri Indian); Big Elk, a Ponca Indian; Big Razor, a Blackfeet Sioux Indian (Yanktonai Indian); Cayatanita, a Navajo Indian; Chief Joseph, a Nez Perce Indian; Clam Fish, a Warm Springs Indian (Warm Spring Apache Indian); Deer Ham, an Ioway Indian (Iowa Indian); Geronimo, an Apache Indian (Chiricahua Apache); Great Bear, a Delaware Indian (Delaware Indian); Grey Eagle, an Apache Indian; John Grass, a Blackfeet Sioux Indian (Sihasapa Indian); John Yellow Flower, a Ute Indian; Keokuk's Son, a Sac & Fox Indian; King of the Crows, a Crow Indian; Lean Wolf, a Gros Ventres Indian (Hidatsa Indian); Man and Chief, a Pawnee Indian; Many Horns, a Blackfeet Sioux Indian (Dakota Indian); Noon Day, a Chippeway Indian (Ojibwa Indian); Red Bird, a Chippeway Indian (Ojibwa Indian); Red Cloud, a Dakota Sioux Indian (Oglala Indian); Red Shirt, a Dakota Sioux Indian (Oglala Indian); Rushing Bear, a Pawnee Indian (Arikara Indian); Striker, an Apache Indian; True Eagle, a Missouria Indian (Missouri Indian); White Shield, a Southern Cheyenne Indian (Cheyenne Indian); Wetcúnie, an Otoes Indian (Oto Indian); and Young Whirlwind, a Southern Cheyenne Indian (Cheyenne Indian).
